original_title: Sri Lanka energy minister instructs to sack “disrupting” protesters amid fuel queues
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’ Power and Energy Minister Kanchana ordered state-run fuel retailer Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC) and its Storage Terminal Limited (CPSTL) chairman to consider sacking trade union activists of the loss-making firms for disrupting normal fuel distribution.

The trade unions in CPC and CPSTL went on leave after two day protest demanding the government to suspend the restructuring of the loss-making CPC. The move hampered the usual fuel distribution, resulting in long queues near filling stations.

“I have instructed Chairman CPC & CPSTL to take necessary disciplinary steps to consider termination of employment & any legal steps necessary against trade union activist or employees that are disrupting the distribution of fuel, disrupting the work of other employees or is acting in violation of the essential services orders,” Minister said in his twitter platform.
“Request the public not to panic over shortages in fuel supply. There’s adequate stocks of fuel in the country & distribution will continue.”

“Fuel distribution that was earlier delayed due to trade union activists forcibly preventing employees from attending to their duties have been normalized with police and armed forces providing necessary security at the terminals & distribution.”
Some government officials said they are considering deploying a military to smooth the fuel distribution.

The government has decided to allow three foreign firms to enter into the local fuel market to increase competition with an aim to improve the service quality. The companies from China, Australia, and the United States will be permitted to operate 200 fuel stations including 150 currently owned by CPC on a 20-year lease.
The decision was taken last year after the country suffered a fuel shortage due to lack of dollars following an unprecedented sovereign debt default.
The CPC and CPSTL trade union activists said the move. which they cited as privatization, will have adverse impacts on the island nation’s energy sector.

The strong trade unions have been long resisting successive governments’ move to restructure the CPC. The cabinet decision to open up the local fuel market comes days after President Ranil Wickremesinghe said the government should not be involved in businesses.  (Colombo/March 28/2023)
